Binge reading, Beards and Biphobia: The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo

19/07/2022

Charis Horsley reviews Taylor Jenkins Reidâ€™s book in relation to modern biphobia

Image by Charis Horsley

By Katy Leverett

Itâ€™s been a while since I last found myself binge reading a book to tears. With the continuous stream of texts to read as an English Literature student, there often isnâ€™t time to root back into the excitement of popular new releases - and sometimes the very necessary safety net of a little bit of trash.

Whatever genre Seven Husbands falls under, the book has been explosively popular and increasingly known throughout the online world. Cara Lee discusses this BookTok culture in her article TikTok made me read it: reading habits in the digital age. Although many have picked up the book because of this social media presence, I ended up with a copy thanks to Yorkâ€™s Tipsygate Readerâ€™s Society. If you enjoy these kinds of reads, (and drinking) itâ€™s worth a look at their Instagram, @tipsygatereaders.

Seven husbands and one true love. Jenkins Reidâ€™s novel is a fictional biography, centred around fame, Hollywood, and, at its core, the battles of bisexuality in the late 20th century.

As a celebrity, Hollywood star Evelyn Hugo leads a dual life, that of her public image and her private reality. Structured through an extended interview, the journalist Monique, strips away the faÃ§ade of fame to reveal the raw truth of her life in the spotlight.

â€˜Who was the love of your life?â€™
Evelyn looks out the window, breathes deeply and then says â€˜Celia St. Jamesâ€™.

Seven husbands. A player and a cheater. The title of the book is intentionally misleading. As the plot progresses, Jenkins Reid reveals the unexpected central union with Celia St. James. Of the seven, only one she romantically desires, and four are a cover for her sexuality.

The title points a finger at the real issue of the novel: societyâ€™s obsession with heterosexuality, even to the point of being blind to what is blatantly before your eyes. Evelyn frequently expresses her reliance on people believing what they wish to believe. If there is an opportunity to see a heterosexual union, then society will find it. With four of the seven husbands playing the role of a â€˜beardâ€™ (a partner used to conceal infidelity or one's sexual orientation), disguising Evelynâ€™s true emotional marriage to Celia, it can be said that for Evelyn marriage does not matter, concluding that, â€œthey are just husbandsâ€. She instead desires the world to understand her love for her one true wife.

Amongst the turmoil of emotions throughout this book, the necessity of her marriages is deeply saddening. She needs Ernie Diaz to lift her from poverty, Don Adler and Mick Riva to boost her career through the public image, and almost all of them to hide her love for Celia. It wasnâ€™t until 2015 that homosexual marriage was legalised in the US. This is an incredibly recent change and underlies the frustration Evelyn feels at being able to marry anyone and everyone except the one woman she loves. Instead, the two women settle for hiding their whole lives, losing decades of time together, and marrying emotionally behind the closed doors of their home. â€œI have been married seven times, and not once has felt half as right as thisâ€. Evelyn walks a fine line between these two existences: that of her public image as a scandalous and straight celebrity and her private self, someone cherishing her family and true love above all else.

Homosexuality aside, Evelyn emphasises that many of her achievements rest upon her use of her body as a currency, the only weapon she has to get what she wants. Her body buys her fame, wealth, a career, and the fickle love of the public. Whatâ€™s more, this currency works every time. As a woman with no wealth, she feels she must climb society through the only means she knows, more often than not, engaging in acts she takes no pleasure in. Shockingly, it wasnâ€™t until 1993 that rape was made illegal within marriage in the US, a luxury Evelyn Hugo did not have. It is this, perhaps, which further emphasises the sanctity of her relations with Celia, the physicality of a love untouched by necessity or currency.

Much of the popularity of this book rests upon its relevance in our changing society today.Â  Frequented by LGBTQ+ audiences, Jenkins Reidâ€™s book resonates with many peopleâ€™s struggles. Although there have been books released recently centred upon gay and lesbian characterisation, Jenkins Reid addresses a whole new issue: that of biphobia. This encompasses prejudice against bisexuality, and having the tendency to label those who are bisexual as either straight or gay, depending on which gender they have been with the most.

Evelyn is insistent throughout the novel: â€œI hate being called a lesbianâ€¦Iâ€™m bisexual. Donâ€™t ignore half of me so you can fit me into a boxâ€. It is this obsession with labelling that Jenkins Reid addresses, the need to label everyone and box them into categories, when perhaps often they are incorrect. Evelyn grows frustrated at the views of those around her: when she loves a man, as she briefly does with Don Adler, she is labelled as a straight woman. When she loves Celia, her lesbian wife feels the need to either view her as a lesbian or feel threatened by male presences, the part she feels she cannot give. In response, Evelyn stresses over and over again: she is capable of loving both, Celia being the love of her life does not shift her into the box of a lesbian.

This can be witnessed in society today. Last week I found myself sipping a blackcurrant spritz at my local pub, (itâ€™s safe to say I wouldnâ€™t order the drink again) with three of my closest friends, two of whom are bisexual. I found myself recommending the book to them, a conversation which quickly progressed onto the topic of biphobia. Someone on the table opposite us, intrigued, chipped in sharing a story of his bisexual ex-wife being rejected on the door of Londonâ€™s popular gay club, Heaven. He commented on labelling and the need for categorisation. â€œAs soon as the bouncer saw she was with me, she was immediately denied entryâ€, he commented. â€œI wasnâ€™t even planning to enter the club. Yet the fact that I was her husband seemed to cancel out any possible queerness. From that moment, in their eyes, she was as straight as a poleâ€.

Another friend in York, upon asserting her bisexuality, is often asked, whether she has ever been with a girl. For some reason, people feel the need to validate sexuality with evidence. If the answer to the question is no, that individual is not any less bisexual than someone who has had 23 girlfriends. Celia St. James follows the same trend with Evelyn Hugo, viewing her six loveless marriages and desire for Celia as cancelling out her attraction to men, and the one husband that she did desire. Upon Moniqueâ€™s questioning, Evelyn becomes assertively defensive, â€œbeing bisexual didnâ€™t make me disloyal, one has nothing to do with the other. Nor did it mean Celia only fulfilled half of my needsâ€. It is this clarity and this message which Evelyn feels are imperative to her biography. For her, the world must not be confused about the nature of her sexuality.

One criticism would be the underdevelopment of Moniqueâ€™s character. Although she is necessary for Evelynâ€™s twist at the end (which I wonâ€™t spoil), she is remarkably insignificant to the plot, and if anything, adds a separate plotline which only confuses readers. Talking to Evelyn helps her realise her divorce, and strengthens her ambition, yet there are so few passages devoted to her, she doesnâ€™t really add much. By the end, Monique is Evelynâ€™s least admiring fan, and yet the reader is still left to make their own mind up on the success of Evelyn Hugoâ€™s narrative, Moniqueâ€™s viewpoint is not necessarily ours.

It is interesting and impressive what Jenkins Reid creates through Evelyn Hugo. The author expresses that her intention was to create a story of two women in love, and yet strongly stresses that it was also about putting a name to bisexuality at the detriment of subtlety in her language, in order to create understanding in bisexual readers. Evelyn is a protagonist who is not moral or entirely admirable: she is branded as manipulative, selfish and a player. Yet, at the end of the novel, the reader is not left disliking her. Many have viewed the novel as a kind of repentance or confession for her life, however I think this stretches too far. Up until the end she remains adamant that she was not a â€œgood personâ€ and despite the outcomes she does not regret her behaviour. Perhaps it is the brutal honesty of an old woman which is so refreshing in a protagonist. She is unapologetic in everything frowned upon as societally unconventional and acknowledges that everything she did was to get her where she got to. Her actions are often painful to read, and yet she sets an impressive premise to pushing the boundaries of ambition. The success of the book lies in its accessibility to LGBTQ+ audiences and relevance to everyone's lives today.
